segment.source: The media player has customizable XAML transport controls to manage control of audio and video content.
segment.target: The media player has customizable XAML transport controls to manage control of audio and video content.

segment.source: Create custom media transport controls
segment.target: Create custom media transport controls

segment.source: Create custom transport controls
segment.target: Create custom transport controls

segment.source: MediaElement has customizable XAML transport controls to manage control of audio and video content within a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: MediaElement has customizable XAML transport controls to manage control of audio and video content within a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: Here, we demonstrate how to customize the MediaTransportControls template.
segment.target: Here, we demonstrate how to customize the MediaTransportControls template.

segment.source: We’ll show you how to work with the overflow menu, add a custom button, modify the slider, and change colors.
segment.target: We’ll show you how to work with the overflow menu, add a custom button, modify the slider, and change colors.

segment.source: Before starting, you should be familiar with the MediaElement and the MediaTransportControls classes.
segment.target: Before starting, you should be familiar with the MediaElement and the MediaTransportControls classes.

segment.source: For more info, see the MediaElement control guide.
segment.target: For more info, see the MediaElement control guide.

segment.source: TipThe examples in this topic are based on the Media Transport Controls sample.
segment.target: TipThe examples in this topic are based on the Media Transport Controls sample.

segment.source: You can download the sample to view and run the completed code.
segment.target: You can download the sample to view and run the completed code.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: MediaElement
segment.target: MediaElement

segment.source: MediaElement.AreTransportControlsEnabled
segment.target: MediaElement.AreTransportControlsEnabled

segment.source: MediaTransportControls
segment.target: MediaTransportControls

segment.source: When should you customize the template?
segment.target: When should you customize the template?

segment.source: MediaElement has built-in transport controls that are designed to work well without modification in most video and audio playback apps.
segment.target: MediaElement has built-in transport controls that are designed to work well without modification in most video and audio playback apps.

segment.source: They’re provided by the MediaTransportControls class and include buttons to play, stop, and navigate media, adjust volume, toggle full screen, cast to a second device, enable captions, switch audio tracks, and adjust the playback rate.
segment.target: They’re provided by the MediaTransportControls class and include buttons to play, stop, and navigate media, adjust volume, toggle full screen, cast to a second device, enable captions, switch audio tracks, and adjust the playback rate.

segment.source: MediaTransportControls has properties that let you control whether each button is shown and enabled.
segment.target: MediaTransportControls has properties that let you control whether each button is shown and enabled.

segment.source: You can also set the IsCompact property to specify whether the controls are shown in one row or two.
segment.target: You can also set the IsCompact property to specify whether the controls are shown in one row or two.

segment.source: However, there may be scenarios where you need to further customize the look of the control or change its behavior.
segment.target: However, there may be scenarios where you need to further customize the look of the control or change its behavior.

segment.source: Here are some examples:
segment.target: Here are some examples:

segment.source: Change the icons, slider behavior, and colors.
segment.target: Change the icons, slider behavior, and colors.

segment.source: Move less commonly used command buttons into an overflow menu.
segment.target: Move less commonly used command buttons into an overflow menu.

segment.source: Change the order in which commands drop out when the control is resized.
segment.target: Change the order in which commands drop out when the control is resized.

segment.source: Provide a command button that’s not in the default set.
segment.target: Provide a command button that’s not in the default set.

segment.source: You can customize the appearance of the control by modifying the default template.
segment.target: You can customize the appearance of the control by modifying the default template.

segment.source: To modify the control's behavior or add new commands, you can create a custom control that's derived from MediaTransportControls.
segment.target: To modify the control's behavior or add new commands, you can create a custom control that's derived from MediaTransportControls.

segment.source: TipCustomizable control templates are a powerful feature of the XAML platform, but there are also consequences that you should take into consideration.
segment.target: TipCustomizable control templates are a powerful feature of the XAML platform, but there are also consequences that you should take into consideration.

segment.source: When you customize a template, it becomes a static part of your app and therefore will not receive any platform updates that are made to the template by Microsoft.
segment.target: When you customize a template, it becomes a static part of your app and therefore will not receive any platform updates that are made to the template by Microsoft.

segment.source: If template updates are made by Microsoft, you should take the new template and re-modify it in order to get the benefits of the updated template.
segment.target: If template updates are made by Microsoft, you should take the new template and re-modify it in order to get the benefits of the updated template.

segment.source: Template structure
segment.target: Template structure

segment.source: The ControlTemplate is part of the default style.
segment.target: The ControlTemplate is part of the default style.

segment.source: The transport control's default style is shown in the MediaTransportControls class reference page.
segment.target: The transport control's default style is shown in the MediaTransportControls class reference page.

segment.source: You can copy this default style into your project to modify it.
segment.target: You can copy this default style into your project to modify it.

segment.source: The ControlTemplate is divided into sections similar to other XAML control templates.
segment.target: The ControlTemplate is divided into sections similar to other XAML control templates.

segment.source: The first section of the template contains the Style definitions for the various components of the MediaTransportControls.
segment.target: The first section of the template contains the Style definitions for the various components of the MediaTransportControls.

segment.source: The second section defines the various visual states that are used by the MediaTransportControls.
segment.target: The second section defines the various visual states that are used by the MediaTransportControls.

segment.source: The third section contains the Grid that holds that various MediaTransportControls elements together and defines how the components are laid out.
segment.target: The third section contains the Grid that holds that various MediaTransportControls elements together and defines how the components are laid out.

segment.source: NoteFor more info about modifying templates, see Control templates.
segment.target: NoteFor more info about modifying templates, see Control templates.

segment.source: You can use a text editor or similar editors in your IDE to open the XAML files in \(Program Files)\Windows Kits\10\DesignTime\CommonConfiguration\Neutral\UAP\\(SDK version)\Generic.
segment.target: You can use a text editor or similar editors in your IDE to open the XAML files in \(Program Files)\Windows Kits\10\DesignTime\CommonConfiguration\Neutral\UAP\\(SDK version)\Generic.

segment.source: The default style and template for each control is defined in the generic.xaml file.
segment.target: The default style and template for each control is defined in the generic.xaml file.

segment.source: You can find the MediaTransportControls template in generic.xaml by searching for "MediaTransportControls".
segment.target: You can find the MediaTransportControls template in generic.xaml by searching for "MediaTransportControls".

segment.source: In the following sections, you learn how to customize several of the main elements of the transport controls:
segment.target: In the following sections, you learn how to customize several of the main elements of the transport controls:

segment.source: Slider: allows a user to scrub through their media and also displays progress
segment.target: Slider: allows a user to scrub through their media and also displays progress

segment.source: CommandBar: contains all of the buttons.
segment.target: CommandBar: contains all of the buttons.

segment.source: For more info, see the Anatomy section of the MediaTransportControls reference topic.
segment.target: For more info, see the Anatomy section of the MediaTransportControls reference topic.

segment.source: Customize the transport controls
segment.target: Customize the transport controls

segment.source: If you want to modify only the appearance of the MediaTransportControls, you can create a copy of the default control style and template, and modify that.
segment.target: If you want to modify only the appearance of the MediaTransportControls, you can create a copy of the default control style and template, and modify that.

segment.source: However, if you also want to add to or modify the functionality of the control, you need to create a new class that derives from MediaTransportControls.
segment.target: However, if you also want to add to or modify the functionality of the control, you need to create a new class that derives from MediaTransportControls.

segment.source: Re-template the control
segment.target: Re-template the control

segment.source: To customize the MediaTransportControls default style and template
segment.target: To customize the MediaTransportControls default style and template

segment.source: Copy the default style from MediaTransportControls styles and templates into a ResourceDictionary in your project.
segment.target: Copy the default style from MediaTransportControls styles and templates into a ResourceDictionary in your project.

segment.source: Give the Style an x:Key value to identify it, like this.
segment.target: Give the Style an x:Key value to identify it, like this.

segment.source: Add a MediaElement with MediaTransportControls to your UI.
segment.target: Add a MediaElement with MediaTransportControls to your UI.

segment.source: Set the Style property of the MediaTransportControls element to your custom Style resource, as shown here.
segment.target: Set the Style property of the MediaTransportControls element to your custom Style resource, as shown here.

segment.source: For more info about modifying styles and templates, see Styling controls and Control templates.
segment.target: For more info about modifying styles and templates, see Styling controls and Control templates.

segment.source: Create a derived control
segment.target: Create a derived control

segment.source: To add to or modify the functionality of the transport controls, you must create a new class that's derived from MediaTransportControls.
segment.target: To add to or modify the functionality of the transport controls, you must create a new class that's derived from MediaTransportControls.

segment.source: A derived class called is shown in the Media Transport Controls sample and the remaining examples on this page.
segment.target: A derived class called is shown in the Media Transport Controls sample and the remaining examples on this page.

segment.source: To create a new class derived from MediaTransportControls
segment.target: To create a new class derived from MediaTransportControls

segment.source: Add a new class file to your project.
segment.target: Add a new class file to your project.

segment.source: In Visual Studio, select Project > Add Class.
segment.target: In Visual Studio, select Project > Add Class.

segment.source: The Add New Item dialog opens.
segment.target: The Add New Item dialog opens.

segment.source: In the Add New Item dialog, enter a name for the class file, then click Add.
segment.target: In the Add New Item dialog, enter a name for the class file, then click Add.

segment.source: (In the Media Transport Controls sample, the class is named .)
segment.target: (In the Media Transport Controls sample, the class is named .)

segment.source: Modify the class code to derive from the MediaTransportControls class.
segment.target: Modify the class code to derive from the MediaTransportControls class.

segment.source: Copy the default style for MediaTransportControls into a ResourceDictionary in your project.
segment.target: Copy the default style for MediaTransportControls into a ResourceDictionary in your project.

segment.source: This is the style and template you modify.
segment.target: This is the style and template you modify.

segment.source: (In the Media Transport Controls sample, a new folder called "Themes" is created, and a ResourceDictionary file called generic.xaml is added to it.)
segment.target: (In the Media Transport Controls sample, a new folder called "Themes" is created, and a ResourceDictionary file called generic.xaml is added to it.)

segment.source: Change the TargetType of the style to the new custom control type.
segment.target: Change the TargetType of the style to the new custom control type.

segment.source: (In the sample, the TargetType is changed to .)
segment.target: (In the sample, the TargetType is changed to .)

segment.source: Set the DefaultStyleKey of your custom class.
segment.target: Set the DefaultStyleKey of your custom class.

segment.source: This tells your custom class to use a Style with a TargetType of .
segment.target: This tells your custom class to use a Style with a TargetType of .

segment.source: Add a MediaElement to your XAML markup and add the custom transport controls to it.
segment.target: Add a MediaElement to your XAML markup and add the custom transport controls to it.

segment.source: One thing to note is that the APIs to hide, show, disable, and enable the default buttons still work with a customized template.
segment.target: One thing to note is that the APIs to hide, show, disable, and enable the default buttons still work with a customized template.

segment.source: You can now modify the control style and template to update the look of your custom control, and the control code to update its behavior.
segment.target: You can now modify the control style and template to update the look of your custom control, and the control code to update its behavior.

segment.source: Working with the overflow menu
segment.target: Working with the overflow menu

segment.source: You can move MediaTransportControls command buttons into an overflow menu, so that less commonly used commands are hidden until the user needs them.
segment.target: You can move MediaTransportControls command buttons into an overflow menu, so that less commonly used commands are hidden until the user needs them.

segment.source: In the MediaTransportControls template, the command buttons are contained in a CommandBar element.
segment.target: In the MediaTransportControls template, the command buttons are contained in a CommandBar element.

segment.source: The command bar has the concept of primary and secondary commands.
segment.target: The command bar has the concept of primary and secondary commands.

segment.source: The primary commands are the buttons that appear in the control by default and are always visible (unless you disable or hide the button).
segment.target: The primary commands are the buttons that appear in the control by default and are always visible (unless you disable or hide the button).

segment.source: The secondary commands are shown in an overflow menu that appears when a user clicks the ellipsis (…) button.
segment.target: The secondary commands are shown in an overflow menu that appears when a user clicks the ellipsis (…) button.

segment.source: For more info, see the App bars and command bars article.
segment.target: For more info, see the App bars and command bars article.

segment.source: To move an element from the command bar primary commands to the overflow menu, you need to edit the XAML control template.
segment.target: To move an element from the command bar primary commands to the overflow menu, you need to edit the XAML control template.

segment.source: To move a command to the overflow menu:
segment.target: To move a command to the overflow menu:

segment.source: In the control template, find the CommandBar element named .
segment.target: In the control template, find the CommandBar element named .

segment.source: Add a SecondaryCommands section to the XAML for the CommandBar.
segment.target: Add a SecondaryCommands section to the XAML for the CommandBar.

segment.source: Put it after the closing tag for the PrimaryCommands.
segment.target: Put it after the closing tag for the PrimaryCommands.

segment.source: To populate the menu with commands, cut and paste the XAML for the desired AppBarButton objects from the PrimaryCommands to the SecondaryCommands.
segment.target: To populate the menu with commands, cut and paste the XAML for the desired AppBarButton objects from the PrimaryCommands to the SecondaryCommands.

segment.source: In this example, we move the to the overflow menu.
segment.target: In this example, we move the to the overflow menu.

segment.source: Add a label to the button and remove the styling information, as shown here.
segment.target: Add a label to the button and remove the styling information, as shown here.

segment.source: Because the overflow menu is comprised of text buttons, you must add a text label to the button and also remove the style that sets the height and width of the button.
segment.target: Because the overflow menu is comprised of text buttons, you must add a text label to the button and also remove the style that sets the height and width of the button.

segment.source: Otherwise, it won't appear correctly in the overflow menu.
segment.target: Otherwise, it won't appear correctly in the overflow menu.

segment.source: ImportantYou must still make the button visible and enable it in order to use it in the overflow menu.
segment.target: ImportantYou must still make the button visible and enable it in order to use it in the overflow menu.

segment.source: In this example, the PlaybackRateButton element isn't visible in the overflow menu unless the IsPlaybackRateButtonVisible property is true.
segment.target: In this example, the PlaybackRateButton element isn't visible in the overflow menu unless the IsPlaybackRateButtonVisible property is true.

segment.source: It's not enabled unless the IsPlaybackRateEnabled property is true.
segment.target: It's not enabled unless the IsPlaybackRateEnabled property is true.

segment.source: Setting these properties is shown in the previous section.
segment.target: Setting these properties is shown in the previous section.

segment.source: Adding a custom button
segment.target: Adding a custom button

segment.source: One reason you might want to customize MediaTransportControls is to add a custom command to the control.
segment.target: One reason you might want to customize MediaTransportControls is to add a custom command to the control.

segment.source: Whether you add it as a primary command or a secondary command, the procedure for creating the command button and modifying its behavior is the same.
segment.target: Whether you add it as a primary command or a secondary command, the procedure for creating the command button and modifying its behavior is the same.

segment.source: In the Media Transport Controls sample, a "rating" button is added to the primary commands.
segment.target: In the Media Transport Controls sample, a "rating" button is added to the primary commands.

segment.source: To add a custom command button
segment.target: To add a custom command button

segment.source: Create an AppBarButton object and add it to the CommandBar in the control template.
segment.target: Create an AppBarButton object and add it to the CommandBar in the control template.

segment.source: In the OnApplyTemplate override, get the button from the template and register a handler for its Click event.
segment.target: In the OnApplyTemplate override, get the button from the template and register a handler for its Click event.

segment.source: This code goes in the class.
segment.target: This code goes in the class.

segment.source: Add code to the Click event handler to perform the action that occurs when the button is clicked.
segment.target: Add code to the Click event handler to perform the action that occurs when the button is clicked.

segment.source: Here's the complete code for the class.
segment.target: Here's the complete code for the class.

segment.source: Modifying the slider
segment.target: Modifying the slider

segment.source: The "seek" control of the MediaTransportControls is provided by a Slider element.
segment.target: The "seek" control of the MediaTransportControls is provided by a Slider element.

segment.source: One way you can customize it is to change the granularity of the seek behavior.
segment.target: One way you can customize it is to change the granularity of the seek behavior.

segment.source: The default seek slider is divided into 100 parts, so the seek behavior is limited to that many sections.
segment.target: The default seek slider is divided into 100 parts, so the seek behavior is limited to that many sections.

segment.source: You can change the granularity of the seek slider by getting the Slider from the XAML visual tree in your MediaOpened event handler.
segment.target: You can change the granularity of the seek slider by getting the Slider from the XAML visual tree in your MediaOpened event handler.

segment.source: This example shows how to use VisualTreeHelper to get a reference to the Slider, then change the default step frequency of the slider from 1% to 0.1% (1000 steps) if the media is longer than 120 minutes.
segment.target: This example shows how to use VisualTreeHelper to get a reference to the Slider, then change the default step frequency of the slider from 1% to 0.1% (1000 steps) if the media is longer than 120 minutes.

segment.source: The MediaElement is named .
segment.target: The MediaElement is named .
